data.title: Autoscroll cursor when attempting to move it, even if it doesn't move
data.body:
Fixes #2723

The model-level autoscroll should always have sat next to the place we emit the 'autoscrolled' event. We should autoscroll even if the cursor doesn't actually move, for example when trying to move down at the end of the file.

data.title: shift-delete does not cut text to clipboard
data.body:
In chromium and in almost every software I have encountered, shift-delete acts as ctrl-x -> it cuts selected text and places it into clipboard. I have used this key combination for great many years, in Dos, Windows and now in Ubuntu 14.04, so it being missing is single most missing feature in Atom for me. 

Can it be fixed? Or maybe there is a way for me to configure it somehow, if nobody else needs it?

thank you in advance!

data.title: Improve default decorations for cursor and selection lines in React editor
data.body:
Fixes #2701

This PR updates the decorations on lines and line numbers in the following way:
- When the cursor is on a certain line, its line and line number will have the `.cursor-line` class.
- When a selection spans lines, their line and line numbers will have the `.selection-line` class.
- If the selection is empty, the cursor's line will _also_ contain the `.cursor-line-no-selection` class. I'd prefer this to be synthesized with `.cursor-line:not(.selection-line)` but we need it for backward compatibility.

Previously, the `.cursor-line` class would be applied to every line number in a selection, but now it's only applied to the line containing the cursor for consistency with what we do on line elements. This means certain themes will need to switch `.line-number.cursor-line` to `.line-number.selection-line` for the same effect. To support these themes in the old editor, we now also add `.selection-line` to the line numbers in the gutter.

Here you can see the line highlight working again in the light theme.
![screenshot 2014-06-27 05 42 26](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1789/3410971/23ee49b2-fdf0-11e3-9192-f708ac393ded.png)

data.body: Hello, I miss the option to switch branch!

data.title: API to open things in Atom or run things in atom
data.body: When downloading certain files, Chrome and other Browsers can automatically allow an app to be opened and the file can be opened there? Can something similar be implemented for Atom packages so people can just browse to [one](https://atom.io/packages/file-icons) and click the cloud which will open and download it in Atom? This is common with torrent files, and that could be very useful.

data.body:
So, there have been a bunch of issues with a similar output but none like mine, especially considering the other environmental differences. And it gets really confusing with two different setups in the same issue, so I opened a new one and tried to include as much information as possible.

 I have tried building on May 9th the last time, where I tried to get help here: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1937#issuecomment-42566756 (and following comments) and I still get a similar error. I didn't change do anything with atom until a few hours ago.

---

Anyway, my config is:
Windows 7x64, VS2010SP1, Python 2.7.5 (but with Python 3.3 as default version)

I ran `npm config set python c:\Python27\python.exe -g` for my older tries to build because that was another problem I was facing, so that is still active if it matters.)

I started the build with:

```
git clean -d
git pull
script\clean
script\build
```

Since I got a bunch of ENOENT errors with something relating `lstat` and long file paths, I did the same as previously and just ran `npm install` on all three folders, `.`, `.\apm` and `.\build`.

Here are the outputs for all builds after that: https://gist.github.com/FichteFoll/1c50260130b97e6d0591 and the most significant and ever-repeating snippet:

```
E:\Development\github\atom\node_modules\git-utils>node "E:\Development\github\atom\apm\node_modules\atom-package-manager\node_modules\npm\bin\node-gyp-bin\\..\..\node_modules\node-gyp\bin\node-gyp.js" rebuild 

gyp
gypnpm ERR! scrollbar-style@0.4.0 install: `node-gyp rebuild`
npm ERR! Exit status 1
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! Failed at the scrollbar-style@0.4.0 install script.
npm ERR! This is most likely a problem with the scrollbar-style package,
npm ERR! not with npm itself.
npm ERR! Tell the author that this fails on your system:
npm ERR!     node-gyp rebuild
npm ERR! You can get their info via:
npm ERR!     npm owner ls scrollbar-style
npm ERR! There is likely additional logging output above.
npm ERR! System Windows_NT 6.1.7601
npm ERR! command "E:\\Development\\github\\atom\\apm\\node_modules\\atom-package-manager\\bin\\\\node.exe" "E:\\Development\\github\\atom\\apm\\node_modules\\atom-package-manager\\node_modules\\npm\\bin\\npm-cli.js" "--globalconfig" "E:\\Development\\github\\atom\\apm\\node_modules\\atom-package-manager\\.apmrc" "--userconfig" "C:\\Users\\marco\\.atom\\.apmrc" "install" "--target=0.11.10" "--arch=ia32" "--quiet" "--msvs_version=2010"
npm ERR! cwd E:\Development\github\atom
npm ERR! node -v v0.10.26
npm ERR! npm -v 1.4.4
npm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE 
```

(Note: I tried setting `GYP_MSVS_VERSION` to `2010` as I read in another issue between build 30 and 32, but since it already detected that as default as indicated by the command log it obviously didn't have any effects.)

---

It was also mentioned in other issues that it was possible for gyp to not find the right MSVS version, but I only had one installed (VS2010). So, after that I tried to check if there might be other prerequisites that I do not fulfill.

Running `node` reveals that it is a 32 bit process, but I tried to install the "Windows 7 64-bit SDK" anyway, which failed with the following log entry:

```
03:26:37 Freitag, 27. Juni 2014: [SDKSetup:Error] Config_Products_Install: Installation of Product Microsoft Windows SDK for Windows 7 (failed): Please refer to Samples\Setup\HTML\ConfigDetails.htm document for further information. Stack:    bei SDKSetup.Product.ConfigureRelatedSfx()       bei SDKSetup.Product.ConfigureNewProduct(ManualResetEvent CancelEvent)
```

Also,
[this](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/931051/3406915/a760177c-fd9a-11e3-8c66-08de05d04bb7.png) is what the install manager showed before, if that matters.

[Here](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/931051/3406918/bd1e1c62-fd9a-11e3-93e7-55867f8b92c6.png) is a list of my "installed software", which includes Visual Studio 2010.

 I read multiple other issues, including #2315 and atom/node-runas#5, but that didn't help me much. I am really lost about this and have no idea what to try, except for what @zcbenz listed [here](https://github.com/atom/node-runas/issues/5#issuecomment-43756658). I'm usually on ##atom (when I'm online) for a quick chat but will be away over the weekend.

data.title: Handle line breaks for Chinese and Japanese properly in automatic wrapping
data.body:
I've found two problems of Atom's soft wrapping:
1. Chinese and Japanese language does not use spaces to separate characters, it causes that Atom treats Chinese sentence as a extremely-long "word" and does not perform correct wrap. According to [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Line_breaking_rules_in_East_Asian_languages], a "CJK Word" is something like `(Opening punctuation)*(Han character | Kana)(Trailing punctuation|Traialing Kana)*`.
2. Atom cannot handle non-monospaced fonts correctly. Han characters and Kanas are much wider than Latin characters.

data.title: Use setImmediate instead of nextTick to batch React editor updates
data.body: Everything I said before about `setImmediate` and `nextTick` was exactly backwards. After trying `setImmediate` again for updates, I see no performance degradation for typing and cursor movement and no flicker when using it within animation frames, so it's a winner. Now we don't need special-case logic for batching updates in animation frames.

data.title: Editor does full screen repaint on scroll after being hidden and shown
data.body:
The mysteries of Chrome's rendering decisions continue. I designed the whole React editor so we wouldn't need to repaint the screen on scroll, and it seemed to be working. But I just discovered that when you switch tabs away from the editor and switch back, the behavior of the render changes and we start repainting the whole screen on scroll.

In the animation below, I refresh, then scroll showing no full screen repaints. Then I switch tabs away and back again and scroll, showing now Chrome is deciding to repaint the screen. :crying_cat_face: 

![repaint](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1789/3393571/59e3eb72-fcc8-11e3-975d-e8f0f52d3550.gif)

data.title: Calling setText() on Editor while it is not attached has no effect
data.body:
I'm currently working with a View that has a mini EditorView as a subview. I'm trying to change the text in the EditorView while it is not attached to the screen. I've been debugging this and it seems that when I call this function: `editorView.getEditor().setText("")` the `editor` member of the EditorView is actually updated and the text is changed to `""`. However the problem is that the EditorView itself is not updated and it still shows the cached text the next time the parent View is attached to the workspace. 

Let's consider this example where I subscribe to a config change event. I added some variables so it's easier to understand what is what. 

``` coffeescript
@subscribe atom.config.observe 'ask-stack.autoDetectLanguage', callNow: false, (autoDetect) =>
      view = this
      editorView = @tagsField
      editor = editorView.getEditor()
      @tagsField.getEditor().setText("") 
```

The `View` is **not attached (or visible) to the workspace when the event is triggered but has been created previously**. The next time the `View` is attached to the workspace I expect the `editorView` text to be blank. What really happens here is that the `editorView` is still showing the previous text (cached I assume). 

Just for the sake of giving more context here's what I get in the debugger:
![Debugger](http://i.imgur.com/m8D4V0y.png)

At this point the `editor` text is empty so this is what we should see when the `view` is attached to the workspace. But this is what I see: 
![Image](http://i.imgur.com/9ZXpODJ.png)

**Important**: When I focus in that mini EditorView the text goes away. I'm guessing this is because the editor is back to an active state and looks for the actual text and the cache is cleared. However I think the text field should be empty before having to focus. 

I also tried to call `redraw()` on the `editorView` after changing the text but **the editorView will completely disappear when calling `redraw()` while the view is not attached to the workspace**. That might be another bug. This is what happens if I call `editorView.redraw()` after setting the text (the 2nd EditorView or text field is gone):
![Image](http://i.imgur.com/jhIeEeU.png) 

A work around is to call `redraw()` right after the next time the `View` is appended to the workspace. However I think this should be done internally and not explicitly in the package code.

data.title: View has no method observeConfig
data.body:
According to the documentation on the [Configuration API](https://atom.io/docs/latest/advanced/configuration) a View object has a `::observeConfig` method that can be used to subscribe to config change events. When I'm using the exact same method in the class initializer (just like in the example) I get the following error: 

```
Failed to activate package named 'ask-stack' TypeError: Object #<AskStackView> has no method 'observeConfig'
```

`AskStackView` extends the `View` model (again just like in the example). 

I am still able to subscribe to a config change using this:

``` coffeescript
atom.config.observe 'ask-stack.autoDetectLanguage', (autoDetect) =>
      @tagsField.getEditor().setText("") unless autoDetect
```

But this is only documented in the API docs and not in the guide.

data.title: Only perform a single synchronous update inside animation frames
data.body:
To fix jitter, commit d57119793bf3f01c94700e2ad4208eac2a71879f changed `requestUpdate` to always perform updates synchronously inside of a `requestAnimationFrame` callback to avoid the use of `nextTick`. However, that changed exposed us to performing multiple redundant updates inside of an animation frame, which hurts performance.

This PR updates the strategy to pause all updates during the animation frame. Then, after the frame's callback, if any updates were requested we perform a single synchronous update. This ensures a maximum of 1 update per frame no matter what.

data.title: Compute pixel rects of cursors and highlights in EditorComponent
data.body:
Fixes #2726

Previously, we were passing the screen ranges of highlights and cursors into their components, then using editor to convert these ranges to pixel positions. This worked for the most part, but when the cursor blinked it could sometimes get out of sync with changes to the model, meaning we asked for a pixel position for a screen position that didn't exist.

This PR changes things to precompute the raw pixel positions for cursors and highlights in the root component and pass it down. When the cursor blinks, we don't need to recompute a pixel position because it's a property that is passed in from the outside and doesn't change in this case.

This kind of approach seems to be what React wants: Compute an immutable snapshot of the model in the root component and pass it down from the top.
